Deforming the de Rham space

Mar 21, 2020

We’ll pick up straight from last time. Grothendieck told us that . We asked: is there a stack such that ? (Recall that a vector bundle with a flat -connection is a -module. By the same argument as in the D-modules case, you find that -modules which are coherent as -modules are actually just vector bundles with a flat -connection.) As -connections are most naturally defined over , we would expect to live over . The fiber over would be the de Rham space , and the fiber over would be (because the associated graded of was ).

This is given by the “deformation to the normal cone”. Let’s recall what this means in topology. If you have two manifolds , then the embedding of inside is diffeomorphic to the normal bundle via the zero section. This is the tubular neighbourhood theorem, and is indispensable in differential topology. In algebraic geometry, you don’t have an exact analogue of this statement; rather, what you have is a flat family, whose fiber at zero is the normal bundle.

More precisely, suppose be a closed immersion. Look at . This lives over , and hence in particular over . Away from , the fiber of is . But at zero (where you’ve blown up), there are two components to the fiber. One component is , while the other component is the projective completion of the normal cone to inside . The exceptional divisor in (i.e., the preimage of under , which is the projectivization of the normal bundle) is identified with the section at of the projective completion. In other words, the “deformation to the normal cone” is the complement . Note that the -action on fixes , and so there’s a -action on the deformation to the normal cone. We’ll actually look at the quotient of the deformation to the normal cone by this -action, and call the resulting object over by .

This is all very concrete. For instance, suppose and is the ideal defining . Then , and is , where is the coordinate on . The fiber at zero is

which (as we said above) has two components. These components are

They intersect along . So, when you remove from , you’re left with . That is the definition of the normal cone. In particular, when you remove from , the fiber away from zero is , while the fiber at zero is the normal cone .

How do we get from this? Look at the diagonal , and form the deformation to the normal cone . This lives over ; the fiber away from is with included via , and the fiber at is the normal bundle of , i.e., the tangent bundle of , with included by the zero section. Then is defined to be (following this paper) the PD-completion of along . Not really sure why you PD complete, so I want another definition.

We can make this a little simpler, at the cost of using fancier words; see Chapter 9 here. Define a cosimplicial scheme via

There is a map , sending the coordinate of to . There is an action of on which makes this map equivariant (scale and ), so you get a cosimplicial stack

Consider the simplicial stack , which lives over . For a given , the fiber away from is , while the fiber at zero is the -fold product of the tangent space (i.e., the normal bundle of the diagonal ). So this is another way of defining the deformation to the normal cone: it’s the stack over . Motivated by this, let’s define

We have a map over . (When , this is the inclusion of into the deformation to the normal cone.) Define as the fiber product

This is a simplicial stack over , and the geometric realization is what we’d like to call . This lives over , and was constructed such that the fiber away from zero is , and the fiber at zero is the normal cone.

It’s a little tedious to prove this, but:

Theorem: There is an equivalence of categories .

Remember from last time that these are exactly filtered D-modules where the action of satisfies Griffiths transversality. The property of being a holonomic D-module should most naturally be phrased in this language. I haven’t yet been able to find a nice way to say what the Lagrangian condition (i.e., codimension of the characteristic variety in the cotangent bundle being as large as possible) is supposed to translate to.

This is very nice. Following this paper, we can then approach the question of what the nonabelian Hodge correspondence is supposed to be. We will return to this in the next post. In fact, I might be giving a talk about this next weekend, so I’ll make slides and notes.
